Contributors
Paul Buchholz is an assistant professor of German Studies at Emory University. He is the author of Private Anarchy: Impossible Community and the Outsider’s Monologue in German Experimental Fiction

After receiving his Ph.D. in German Studies from Cornell University in 2010, he held a postdoctoral position at New York University and worked as an assistant professor in the German Departments at Scripps College and the University of California, Berkeley. Buchholz’s research focuses on German-​language prose of the twentieth and twenty-​first centuries, with an emphasis on how the experiments with narrative form complicate commonplace ideas of human community

container-title: Feiner. Leichter: Nuancierungen zum Werk Robert Wal­sers (2010) and Malicious Objects, Anger Management, and the Question of Modern Literature (2012) and coeditor of Die Amerikanischen Götter: Transatlantische Prozesse in der Deutschsprachigen Popkultur seit 1945
title: Jörg Kreienbrock is an associate professor of German and comparative literature at Northwestern University. His research focuses on German literature from the eighteenth to the twenty-​first centuries, with an emphasis on literary theory, contemporary literature, the history of science, and popular culture. Professor Kreienbrock is the author of Kleiner

Elke Siegel is an associate professor in the Department of German Studies at Cornell University. She is the author of Aufträge aus dem Bleistiftgebiet: Zur Dichtung Robert Wal­sers (2001) and Entfernte Freunde: Nietzsche, Freud, Kafka und die Freundschaft der Moderne

Further publications include articles on twentieth-​century and contemporary German-​language literature; literature and film; writing and the Internet; the diaristic as interface between life and writing, subject and world, self and history, fiction and nonfiction
